_header: Thy greyhound must be headed like a snake
Note:
Formerly 42.5; Tilley (1950)
XTilley, Morris Palmer. A Dictionary of the Proverbs in England in the 16th and 17th Centuries. Ann Arbor, MI: University of Michigan, 1950 S 283; bad key, TP 18.5; Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 2.
_description: The qualities of a good greyhound — varying numbers of couplets or couplets and triplets

BLEge1995.Transcription:
Thy greyhounde moste be heddyd lyke a snakeI neckyd lyke a
                    drakeI brestyde lyke a lyonI fotyd lyke a noyuonI
                    syded lyke a noyuonI fotyde lyke a catteI taylyd lyke a
                    ratteThenne ys the grehounde welle I shapte
BLEge1995.Attributed Title:
The Condyscyons of A grehounde ande of hys propyrnyng propyrteys
                    (f. 55v)
BLEge1995.Editions:
Mooney,  Linne R. 
             “Practical Didactic Works in Middle English.” 
         Diss. Toronto, 1981: 433.

TCD661.Transcription:
he shuld be heddyd lyke a snakeand nekkyd lyke a drakefootyd
                    lyke a cattTaylled lyke a rattSydyd lyke a temeand chyned lyke a
                    beme
TCD661.Attributed Title: The properties of a good greyhounde (p. 64)
